text:
171-187 Cherry Street, south side, east from, but not including Market Slip, to the Manhattan Bridge. Nos. 171-173 is the Madonna House, a Roman Catholic Retreat.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 173 Cherry Street, the private residence with the statue of the Madonna over the door is the former home of Alexander Hamilton. For an account of a visit to this Nunnery and an insight into it's activities, see the N. Y. Times of March 4th, 1940 page 12: "About New York" by Meyer Berger.

(1) Market Slip, west side, south from Cherry Street, to the East River. The Brooklyn Bridge is shown in the background. Market Slip is a continuation of Market Street, south of Cherry Street.

September 24, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a closer view of Nos. 95-99 Market Slip, at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of Water Street,

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Market Slip - Cherry Street

text:
Feast of San Rocco, (St. Roch), 1929, No. 13. Showing a group of young girls carrying a candelabrum in the procession. The same as views Nos. 4, 7, 9 and 10,12.

August 16, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

No. 14: The same farther eastward. The marchers are on Cherry Street at Market Slip. Arching the street is the Manhattan Bridge anchorage.

August 16, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

158-158½ Cherry Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Market Street.
March 9, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Cherry Street, west from and including Market Slip. The view shows the Brooklyn Bridge in the background (with a general view of the southern portion of the city).

June 8, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, but from a different angle. Also shown is Market Slip, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Cherry Street.

176-178 Cherry Street, north side, east of Market Street. Building shown is a 1-story frame structure, with a small portion (178) of brick.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST

(1) Market Slip, east side, north from but not including Water, to and including Cherry Streets. Also shown (a continuation north of Cherry Street), is Market Street, north from and including Cherry Street. The view shows Cherry Street, north side, at Market Street. A breadline of mendicants is shown encircling the block on the right. March 9, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a different angle.

March 9, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Celebrations: Ceremonies corner Cherry and Market Streets, marking demolition Of Lower East side tenements. Governor Alfred E. Smith struck the first blow. Buildings will be replaced with model Housing developments.

Associated Press Photo.

October 14, 1933.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - [Ceremony of marking demolition of Lower east side tenements - Governor Alfred E. Smith.]

text:
(1)
Feast of San Rocco (St. Roch), 1933, No. 1. Parade, bearing the statue of St. Roch, marching west on Cherry Street at Market Slip.
The structure in the background is the Manhattan Bridge Anchorage. August 16, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 2. Parade, moving west on Oak Street, at the corner of New Chambers Street. August 16, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 3. The same, a little later, showing a group of young girls carrying the American flag. August 16, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of San Rocco [Saint Roch].

Cherry Street, north side, west from and including Market, to and including Catherine Streets. Knickerbocker Village is shown in the process of erection.

(1) Cherry Street, west from but not including Market Street, and showing a general view of lower Manhattan and the Brooklyn Bridge. The structural frame work for Knickerbocker Village appears in the foreground.

March 6, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a further view westward.

March 6, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Cherry Street, north side, at Market Street. Also shown is Market Street, west side, north from Cherry, to and including Madison Street. The view shows the steel structure for Knickerbocker City.

March 30, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO
BE EAST AND WEST

Market Slip, west side, north from and including Water, to and including Cherry Streets. Also shown is Water Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Market Slip. Structural frame work for Knickerbocker Village appears in the background.

March 6, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

The white corner structure, (No. 98 Market Slip), the one story garage adjacent and five story tenement (No. 428 Water Street) are to be demolished by the New York City Housing Authority, according to the New York Sun of September 12, 1938.
title: Manhattan: Market Slip - Cherry Street

text:
84-90 Market Slip, east side, south from Cherry, to, and including Water Streets. This building, formerly occupied by the White Dental Co. has been converted into a Music School under the auspices of the Madonna House; a Roman Catholic organization occupying the adjoining structure on Cherry Street; No. 171. On the extreme right appears No. 433 Water St., a 5 story building at the S. E. corner Market Slip. The Manhattan Bridge traverses the entire background.

P. L. Sperr.

August 16, 1935.
title: Manhattan: Market Slip - Cherry Street
